channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Vatican’s Secret Rules for Priests Who Have Children
item.media:description: “It’s the next scandal,” said Vincent Doyle, the son of a priest. “There are kids everywhere.”
item.media:credit: Suzanne Kreiter/Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.description: The Vatican confirmed, apparently for the first time, that it has general guidelines for what to do when clerics break celibacy vows and father children.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Trump Delivers Blunt Warning to Venezuela Military Over Aid Impasse
item.media:description: Colombian security forces stand guard in front of shipping containers placed by Venezuelan security forces to block the border bridge that connects Colombia to Venezuela.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Trump warned Venezuelan soldiers to renounce loyalty to President Nicolás Maduro or they will find “no safe harbor.”
item.dc:creator: ANNIE KARNI, NICHOLAS CASEY and ANATOLY KURMANAEV

item.title: Anti-Semitic Taunts by Yellow Vests Prompt French Soul-Searching
item.media:description: A Yellow Vest protest in Paris on Saturday.
item.description: The insults hurled at Alain Finkielkraut, a prominent intellectual, crystallized a number of dark elements in a climate of public tension.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Justin Trudeau’s Political Crisis Widens as Top Aide and Friend Resigns
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada on his way to a cabinet meeting last year with his senior advisor, Gerald Butts, who resigned on Monday.
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Rather than calming the growing political storm over allegations that Mr. Trudeau’s government tried to interfere in a criminal court case, the resignation of Gerald Butts could intensify it.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: 7 Labour Lawmakers Resign in U.K., in Rebuke of Jeremy Corbyn
item.media:description: Members of Britain’s opposition Labour Party pressing this month for a second referendum on membership in the European Union.
item.description: The decision reflects the strains that Brexit has placed on a political system dominated by two main parties, each plagued by schisms.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Vatican Hopes Meeting on Child Sex Abuse Will Be a Turning Point
item.media:description: Cardinal Blase J. Cupich, Chicago Archbishop, right, with Mons. Chales Scicluna, Malta Archbishop at a press conference on the Vatican summit.
item.description: Church leaders spoke of demanding accountability and transparency, but there have been similar calls in the past and change has been slow.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Shinzo Abe Won’t Say if He Nominated Trump for a Nobel Prize
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, center left, with President Trump during the Group of 20 summit meeting in Buenos Aires in November.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Such an nomination would be in keeping with the Japanese leader’s careful courting of the United States president. Critics said it would be “shameful for Japan.”
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: As Trump Attacks Maduro, Some See Bid for Florida Votes
item.media:description: President Trump addressed Miami’s Venezuelan community during a speech at Florida International University on Monday.
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.description: President Trump went to Miami not only to warn Nicolás Maduro that his days as Venezuela’s leader were numbered, but also to court a key bloc of voters ahead of the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: ANNIE KARNI and PATRICIA MAZZEI

item.title: Kashmir Militants Kill Again as Trouble Grows Between India and Pakistan
item.media:description: Flames and smoke billowing from a residential building during a gun battle between militants and Indian security forces in the Pulwama District of the Kashmir Valley on Monday.
item.description: An army major was among the dead during raids by Indian forces in the wake of a huge truck bombing that killed dozens of soldiers last week.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and SAMEER YASIR

item.title: Australia’s Prime Minister Blames ‘Sophisticated State Actor’ for Parliament Hack
item.description: Australia has been unable to determine which country was behind a hack of Parliament and the country’s political parties weeks before a national election.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE TARABAY

item.title: Saudi Crown Prince Promises $20 Billion in Investments for Pakistan
item.media:description: Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan, center left, with Saudi Arabia’s crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, in Islamabad on Monday.
item.media:credit: Pakistan’s Press Information Department, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The pledges, which are nonbinding, would also help secure the country as a market for Saudi crude oil.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s ‘Butler’ Visits Vietnam to Prepare for Trump Meeting
item.media:description: A motorcade carrying Kim Chang-son, a close aide to North Korea’s leader, leaving a government guesthouse in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Saturday.
item.description: North Korean officials were said to have checked out an industrial area that contains a Samsung plant, raising the possibility of a visit there by Mr. Kim.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: The English Voice of ISIS Comes Out of the Shadows
item.media:description: Mohammed Khalifa, a 35-year-old Canadian citizen who was born in Saudi Arabia and is of Ethiopian descent, says he is the narrator of multiple English-language Islamic State videos.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: For years, an anonymous narrator extolled the Islamic State’s brutality in videos seen around the world. “I don’t regret it,” a Canadian captured in Syria says.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Rift Between Trump and Europe Is Now Open and Angry
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Munich on Saturday. She pushed back against his call for European allies to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal.
item.description: Europeans pushed back against the Trump administration’s unilateralism at the Munich Security Conference, signaling a shift that is likely to be exploited by Russia and China.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Donald Trump, Labour Party, Huawei: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Colombian security forces standing guard in front of a blockade of shipping containers placed by Venezuelan security forces at the border.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: PENN BULLOCK

item.title: Huawei Founder Slams U.S. Charges as ‘Politically Motivated’
item.media:description: Ren Zhengfei, the founder of Huawei, has become more publicly critical about the arrest of his daughter Meng Wanzhou, the company’s chief financial officer.
item.description: Ren Zhengfei had previously avoided passing judgment on the case, citing respect for the legal process. Now he appears to be sharpening his language.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Murders of Religious Minorities in India Go Unpunished, Report Finds
item.media:description: Villagers mourn a cattle trader killed by a mob in Kolgaon, India, last year.
item.description: Human Rights Watch said the police have stalled investigations into some vigilante-style murders of Muslims and lower-caste Indians.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Honda Plans to Leave Britain as Brexit Draws Close
item.description: The Japanese automaker, which employs 3,500 at its Swindon, England, plant, is set to close the site by 2021, two members of Parliament said.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Cancellation of Pakistan Trip Revives Debate Over Taliban’s Ability to Travel
item.media:description: An unofficial Afghan delegation meeting with Taliban negotiators in Moscow this month.
item.description: The Afghan government lodged a protest with the United Nations saying the insurgent group was violating travel restrictions under international sanctions.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: China, the Vatican, Kashmir: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Survivors of clergy sex abuse outside St. Peter’s Square at the Vatican.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Bonaire: Where Coral and Cactus Thrive, and the Sea Soothes the Soul
item.media:description: Nina Burleigh, the author, dives near the Pink Beach snorkel site off the coast of Bonaire. The Caribbean island offers a beacon of hope for coral reefs.
item.media:credit: Erik Freeland for The New York Times
item.description: In a dying reef world, the writer explores the underwater bliss of a little Caribbean island that is showing the world just how to save coral.
item.dc:creator: NINA BURLEIGH

item.title: Lens: The Disappearing Chimney Sweeps of Paris
item.description: With the romanticized but dangerous and dirty trade languishing, Pete Hawk captured chimney sweeps at work, toiling above treetops in the City of Light.
item.dc:creator: PETE HAWK and EVELYN NIEVES

item.title: Poland and Israel Try to Improve Ties, but History Intrudes
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, right, with Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki of Poland at the Middle East summit in Warsaw last week.
item.description: Israel’s prime minister is trying to turn strange bedfellows into staunch allies, but the past keeps creeping up to derail things.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER and MARC SANTORA

item.title: Brexit: For Wall Street Banks in London, It’s Moving Time
item.media:description: London’s financial district, Canary Wharf. Few expect London to lose its might overnight, but international banks will no longer view it as their best gateway in or out of Europe.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: One thing is clear about the legacy of Brexit: Financial services will be spread across Europe, with no one city again dominating the financial arena as London has.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

item.title: ‘Show Me That My Father Is Alive.’ China Faces Torrent of Online Pleas.
item.media:description: Murat Harri Uyghur, a doctor in Finland, is helping to compile testimonies from other Uighurs in exile about loved ones who may be in Chinese internment camps.
item.media:credit: Meeri Koutaniemi for The New York Times
item.description: China is detaining vast numbers of Uighurs and other Muslims, and friends and relatives are making their names public to put pressure on Beijing.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: More Clues, and Questions, in 1961 Crash That Killed Dag Hammarskjold
item.media:description: Officials searching through debris after the plane carrying Dag Hammarskjold crashed in Northern Rhodesia.
item.media:credit: Central Press/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.description: A documentary film claims to have new information, which a United Nations investigator is evaluating. But after nearly six decades, nothing is definitive.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: In Center of Catholicism, New Mormon Temple Invites Curious Romans for a Look
item.media:description: The new temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Rome. Nonmembers were being allowed to tour the temple before its dedication.
item.description: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is opening an enormous temple in Rome, and intrigued Italians are taking the opportunity to glimpse inside.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)

item.title: Teenage ISIS Member Who Wants to Return to U.K. Gives Birth
item.description: Shamima Begum, 19, had expressed little regret for joining the terrorist group but wanted to return home to protect the health of her child. Her son was born in a refugee camp.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Russian Flag Flies on Cathedral in English Town Where Ex-Spy Was Poisoned
item.description: The stunt came two weeks before the anniversary of a nerve-agent attack on a former Russian spy in Salisbury, England.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Karl Marx’s Tomb in London Is Splashed With Red Paint
item.media:description: Karl Marx’s memorial in Highgate Cemetery in London has been vandalized twice in less than two weeks.
item.description: It was the second time in less than two weeks that the memorial in Highgate Cemetery was defaced. Vandals previously took a hammer to the marble slab.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: India Dispatch: ‘The Pirate Days Are Over’: Goa’s Nude Hippies Give Way to India’s Yuppies
item.media:description: An Indian tourist lounging in the surf on a Goa beach last month, as a friend took a picture.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: As newly middle-class Indians flock to Goa’s beaches, residents of the former countercultural enclave worry its laid-back, tolerant vibe will be disrupted by the visitors’ more conservative mores.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: Land Mines Block Saudi-Led Assault in Yemen, Killing Civilians
item.media:description: A mountain of land mines that Yemeni soldiers said they collected over the past two months. The mines have stymied the Saudi-led advance.
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of land mines have stymied the Saudi-led forces in Yemen, and could pose a danger to civilians for decades to come.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: U.S. Military Starts Flying Aid for Venezuela to Colombia
item.media:description: The border crossing with Venezuela, as seen from Cúcuta, Colombia.
item.description: The shipments of humanitarian aid aboard Air Force planes come as the Pentagon is preparing for the possibility of missions in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘No One Survived.’ A Taliban Attack Kills 32 at Remote Afghan Post.
item.description: The attack on the small base was the latest in a series of deadly Taliban ambushes of Afghan security outposts.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and DAVID ZUCCHINO
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: News Analysis: Among European Allies, Americans Offer Competing Visions
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence during his speech at the annual Munich Security Conference. His predecessor, Joseph Biden, also spoke.
item.description: Remarks by the current vice president and his predecessor defined the dramatic change in American foreign policy that has unnerved traditional allies.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS and DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Albania Protesters Clash With Police at Rally Called by Opposition
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition party gathered for an antigovernment protest in front of the office of Prime Minister Edi Rama’s Socialist Party in Tirana on Saturday.
item.description: Thousands of opposition supporters took to the streets on Saturday at an anti-government rally calling for the cabinet to resign and for early elections.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Emiliano Sala’s Grieving Argentine Hometown Bids Farewell
item.media:description: A banner reading “Emi, you will never walk alone” outside the soccer boyhood club of Emiliano Sala in Progreso, Argentina, on Saturday.
item.description: The 28-year-old soccer striker died when the small plane he was traveling in went down in the English Channel.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Merkel Rejects U.S. Demands That Europe Pull Out of Iran Nuclear Deal
item.media:description: At the Munich Security Conference on Saturday, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany delivered a spirited defense of multilateral institutions in a world increasingly marked by great power rivalry.
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany delivered a spirited defense of multilateral institutions in a world increasingly marked by great power rivalry.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Bruno Ganz, Who Played an Angel and Hitler, Is Dead at 77
item.media:description: Bruno Ganz was born in Zurich, the son of a Swiss mechanic and his Italian wife.
item.description: “Wings of Desire” and “Downfall” were among the highlights of Mr. Ganz’s long film career, which he spent mostly in Europe.
item.dc:creator: ANITA GATES

item.title: Spain’s Far-Right Vox Party Sees Breakout Moment in New Election
item.media:description: Migrants on their way home after working in the greenhouses in El Ejido, in southern Spain, where the far-right Vox party has taken root.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: The party got its breakthrough in a southern coastal farming region, where migration was an issue. Now it’s hoping for success at the national level.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: The President, the Envoy and the Talib: 3 Lives Shaped by War and Study Abroad
item.media:description: Mr. Ghani, Mr. Stanekzai and Mr. Khalilzad now. As young men Mr. Ghani and Mr. Khalilzad studied in Beirut and earned doctorates at American universities. Mr. Stanekzai trained at prestigious Indian military schools.
item.media:credit: Denis Balibouse/Reuters; Pavel Golovkin/Associated Press; Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: They were scholarship students in the 1970s, and now they are all at center stage of the drama surrounding American talks with the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: 11th-Hour Delay of Nigeria’s Presidential Election Disappoints Millions
item.media:description: Nigerians checking their names on voting lists in Jimeta on Saturday. The country’s electoral watchdog postponed presidential and parliamentary elections for one week, hours before polls were to open.
item.description: Officials announced the postponement by one week in an already tense race hours before the polls were to open. The change is expected to thin turnout.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and EMMANUEL AKINWOTU

item.title: Pope Defrocks Theodore McCarrick, Ex-Cardinal Accused of Sexual Abuse
item.media:description: Theodore E. McCarrick, a former cardinal and archbishop of Washington, was expelled from the priesthood after he was found guilty of sexual abuse.
item.description: The move by Pope Francis, announced by the Holy See on Saturday, was the first time a cardinal in the United States has been removed from the priesthood.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH DIAS and JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Canada Letter: The Strange Story Behind the SNC-Lavalin Affair
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau last month with Jody Wilson-Raybould, who quit his cabinet this week.
item.description: Eight months before the federal election, a cabinet minister’s resignation and allegations of improper influence have Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in a political crisis.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Nigeria Postpones Election Just Hours Before Polls Open
item.media:description: Election material awaiting distribution in Yola, Nigeria, on Friday.
item.description: The electoral commission delayed the vote until Feb. 23, citing unspecified “challenges” amid reports that voting materials had not been delivered to all parts of the country.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Millionaire Brothers Wanted by Ecuador Are Arrested in Miami by ICE
item.media:description: Roberto Isaías in Miami in 2014. He and his brother William were arrested Wednesday and taken to a detention facility where undocumented immigrants are held pending deportation.
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.description: Roberto and William Isaías, convicted of embezzlement in Ecuador, were arrested Wednesday, according to the Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Border Wall, Illinois, Colin Kaepernick: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: In Eastern Europe, U.S. Officials Talk Deals, Not Erosion of Democracy
item.media:description: A protest against the planned reorganization of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences in Budapest on Tuesday.
item.description: Promoting weapons sales and isolation of Iran, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Vice President Mike Pence did not speak out on the illiberal direction of some allies.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

German Marshall Fund of the United States
